speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: In the jook houses and doing any kind of work at all, chopping wood and in the lumber camps and everywhere you find this song. No where you can't find parts of this song, 'Mule on the Mount'.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, is it known, is it a consistent song as you hear it all over?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: The tune is consistent but the verses, you know how things, in every locality you can find some new verses, everywhere.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I mean does it have the same choral verses? Does it have 'Mule on the Mount' wherever you hear it?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, there's some place that I haven't heard that same verse 'Mule on the Mount' but there's no place that I don't hear some of the same verses.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where did you learn it this particular way?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, I heard the first verses, I got it in my native village of Eatonville, Florida from George Thomas.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And this is one version you're going to sing?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I'm going to sing, oh I guess, all the tune is the same. I'm going to sing verses from a whole lots of places.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: When you hear that sung, or nearly sung, about how many verses does a man know? He doesn't know as many as you do.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Yes, sometimes they sing 30 and 40 verses.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Is one of these continuous?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: It's one of these things that's grown by incremental repetition until perhaps it's the longest song in America.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [inaudible]

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Zora Neale Hurston laughs [distortion]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What's your name, please?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Beatrice Lange.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where do you come from?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: I came from South Georgia.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where? What part of South Georgia?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Woodbine.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And how old are you?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And what are you going to tell us or?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Well, I'm going to tell some folk stories that my brother-in-law told me.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How long ago?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: About a year ago.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: A short, a short while back.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Well, it happened longer than that but he told me about a year ago.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I mean, how did it, it happened long ago . . . what do you mean by that?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: I mean that the story happened longer than that.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, how did it go? I mean how did it --

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Well, this old negro of his told him about it. The negro belonged to his father.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh-huh

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Who had a rice plantation.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: The negro told it to him when? I mean did he ever tell you that?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: About six months to a year ago.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I mean the negro had just told him the story?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Yes, while he was working with him.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I see. And you don't have any name for it? Is that right?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Well, uh, it's a storm story, a hurricane story.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Just, okay, [laughing] go ahead .

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: I have several stories though. This is just one.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, let's start off with just one. That's the easiest way.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Alright, sir.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright. Well, can you tell it or are you going to tell it or read it?

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Well I can kind of glance at it.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright. Go ahead.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Uh, this story happened during the fall of 1898 upon a small island off of the coast of Georgia

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Where the sea level was very low. Came a hurricane which covered the whole island in several feet of water and most of the natives had to swim around in their homes.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: One particular instance which calls to mind is that of an old negrum owned by one of the early rice planters.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: He tells: Yes sir, we were swimming around in that water trying to find a shallow place when we seen some of them pretty long neck bottles floating around. Look like them water in 'em.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: So we drink some and before long we was glad to have some been come because it sure made us feel good. Sure wish I could have some of that stuff now. Boss, I believe that been shampoo.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Further on the flooded plantation, the boss paddled his canoe up to the loft of the barn.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: There sat another of his n-- with a big stick in his hand as if he was going to strike something. Even that the hole in the side of the barn where the [inaudible] was stored had looked as if a board had been torn off. He glanced over in the corner and there'n a pile of dead coons which looked like a hundred or so.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: As the boss approached, he said, 'By grade, Tom, what have you been doing here?' He replied in a dramatic voice, 'Boss, I's just been praying all the time, how's that good for the ole master to come take this water back where it belong so we's could get back to work. Boss, I've been a praying every chance that I'm got to liberation.' 'Well, from the looks of the coons you killed, you didn't have time to pray much, Tom'. 'Mass Donald,  I wouldn't have killed 'em but they kept barring me from praying all the time.'

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Another story I told of an old native of Georgia came to Florida in the nineties to seek adventure. This old cracker who really lived in the backwoods had a name of being the biggest liar in the country.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now look, suppose you don't read it from there and you just tell me it as a story. Go ahead. You can do it.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Just let me glance at it.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright. Go ahead.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: [Laughter]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: He said me and my son Israel, we went down to Floridy to pick oranges. Huh. They grow so big you can fill a water bucket full with four of 'em.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: The alligators, they were so tame, and I bet we had about a hundred and fifty, every day we went down to the palmetto patch and whistled and they would come running under the palmetto patch at me and crawl up on my shoulders and talk to me.

speaker: Beatrice Lange
words: Why down there we cut down the palmetto trees to make fence posts and they is the best you ever seen. They would last a hundred years. I know because I tried them twice.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Surely, but I have to give all that other data.  My name is Zora Neale Hurston and I'm going to sing a gambling song that I collected at Boston Florida. Turpentine is still there. And the men are playing a game called Georgia Skin. That's the most favorite gambling scheme among the workers of the South. And they lose money on the drop of a card, the fall of a card. And there's a rhythm to the fall of the card and after they get set with the two principles and the other people are called pikers and anybody that wants a special card, he pick it out and they call that, uh, picking one in the rough.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I think it's better if you explain just how the cards, which way the cards get out or how people are standing there before you go on.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, you see, they take a deck of cards and they shuffle it real good and watch the man to be sure he don't steal nothing. That is, that he don't set a cub. There are four cards of every kind in the deck. And when the card like the card you have selected falls, you lose. Sometimes if you don't watch the dealer he'll put three cards just like his own down at the bottom of the deck so that everybody falls before he does and then he wins all the money.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, what does he do? Is the dealer holding the deck of cards?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: And he puts it on the table. They don't allow him to hold it because they're afraid he'll steal.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: So they, he puts it on the table and he turns over a card.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: He just turns over . . .

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Card by card and if the card is just like yours, when it falls, you lose. And, uh, so they holler when he gets all set, when the principles has got their cards and the pikers has got theirs and then the man will say he wants them to put the bets down and he'll say 'Put the money on the wood, and make the bet go good and then again, put it insight and save a fight' and so they all get the bets down and then he start and they'll holler, 'Let the deal go down, boys, let the deal go down'.  And someone will start singing.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Uncle Bud is not a work song. It's a sort of social song for amusement and it's so widely distributed, it's growing all the time by incremental repetition, and it is known all over the South. No matter where you go you can find verses of Uncle Bud. And, uh, it's a favorite song. And the men get to working in every kind of work and they just yell down on Uncle Bud and nobody particular leads it. Everybody puts in his verse when he gets ready and Uncle Bud goes and goes and goes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What, is it sung before the respectable ladies?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Never! It's one of those jook songs and the woman that they sing Uncle Bud in front of is a jook woman.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I thought you heard it from women?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Yes, I heard it from women [laughs].

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Is there more to it?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I know I know some more verses but right off I don't recall.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I think that's a very valuable contribution to scientific recording.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Oh the Buford Boat Done Come' is a song from the Geechee country in South Carolina but I heard it down in Florida from a Geechee that moved down in Florida. I forget her name right now.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, what type of song is it?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: It's a little dance song with a Charleston rhythm.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How do they play it? Would you tell us very quickly?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Uh, it's just a dance song and then they dance a Charleston rhythm on it.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Was it, is it solo dancing?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: No, group dancing.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, what kind of group is it?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Oh, just any group, any working group, and they'll clap their hands on it and sing.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I'm a sing a blues, 'Cuz Ever Been Down', and I got it at Palm Beach from a fellow named from Johnny Bardon.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where did you get it

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I got it in 1933.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Can you tell me, do you know how old a Blues it is? And how you happened to learn it?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, it's one of those things just go around all the jooks and what not like that and it goes by incremental repetition, a verse here and a verse there. I don't suppose anybody knows how old it is and when it started.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I heard 'Halimuhfack' down on the East Coast.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Who did you hear it from and when?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I don't remember. I was in a big crowd and I learned it in the evening during the crowd. And I'm just, don't can't exactly remember who I, who did teach it to me but I learned it from the crowd most exactly more from one.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: You said you learned it in a crowd. How do you learn most of your songs?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I learn them. I just get in the crowd with the people if they singing and I listen as best I can and I start to joining in with a phrase or two and then finally I get so I can sing a verse and then I keep on until I learn all the songs, all the verses, and then I sing them back to the people until they tell me that I can sing them just like them and then I take part and I try it out on different people who already know the song until they are quite satisfied that I know it and then I carry it in my memory.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well how about those that you have in your books and publish in the journals?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Well, that's the same way I got them. I learn the song myself and then I can take it with me wherever I go because I -- [cut off]

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: This is a song, uh, called 'Tampa'. I've known it ever since I could remember so I don't know who taught it to me but I heard it sung in my native village when I was a child, not in front of the old folks, of course.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: You say that was uh. . . when was that sung?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I've known it all my life. No, it was not confined to children. Everybody sung and danced on it. And you hear a Negro orchestra, a local orchestra, they often played it now, played the tune. They don't sing the words but the tune is one of their favorite dance tunes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: This one. Some of them call it 'Po Boy' and some of them call it 'Po Gal' but it's a pretty well-distributed blues tune all over the South. The words are not rhymed. It's a typical Negro pattern. The same line repeated three times with a sort of flip line on the end and the change is in the tune rather than the words for the most part.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where did you pick up the way you sing it?

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: I'm - no, not all my life but I kept learning verses as I've gone around.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: How do you want this?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Just play it for me in ballad.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: Mama Don't Want No Peas No Rice' is a song from Nassau in the Bahama islands. They are great song makers and their tunes are decidedly more African than the ones made by the negroes in America. They make songs so rapidly they say 'Anything you do we put you in sing'. And in a few hours they have a song about it. Mama don't want no peas no rice is about a woman who wanted to stay drunk all the time and her husband is really complaining about it. He's explaining to the neighbors what's the matter with his wife and why they don't get along better.

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Your name, age?

speaker: Evelyn Werner
words: Evelyn Werner, 32.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And where were you brought up?

speaker: Evelyn Werner
words: I was born and raised in Jacksonville, studied voice in Chicago but never went to college.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh, huh, What do you mean 'voice'? Singing?

speaker: Evelyn Werner
words: Yes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh-huh, Alright. But you were brought up, most of your life, you spent right around here?

speaker: Evelyn Werner
words: Well, as far as the life goes, yes but I'd go to Philadelphia for a while and come back and go to Chicago for a while and come back.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright, now you'll tell the story. Apparently the interest in the story is just to have you talk naturally and at the same time, we'll have the story. So, would you try --

speaker: Unknown
words: Man: Go ahead.

speaker: Evelyn Werner
words: Well, this story was told to me two years ago by one of the heirs to the Reed Plantation, Mulberry Grove, which is just south of Jacksonville. She said that right after the war when the slaves were freed she gave, she told Mariah the cook of her freedom and gave her the house at the end of the field to live in. So Mariah and all of her children set out and the youngest and the tiniest at the end of the line would fall down and get up, fall down again and get up.  So Mrs. Pearson called to Mariah and said, 'You're losing one of your children, Mariah'. And Mariah turned back and said, 'You can have that one, Miss. Pearson, if you wants it.' That's all.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Dr. Corse would you please explain why we asked to have this record made?

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: This record was made for the purpose of recording the annunciation of an educated Southern white voice. And the story was one which was recorded by the Federal Writers as part of their work for the American guide series volume that's Florida.

speaker: Unknown
words: Educated white woman.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Dr. Corse will you please introduce the speaker?

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: This is Mrs. Rolla Southworth, State Director of the Professional Service Projects of the WPA in Florida who will give us her opinion of the recording program of the folk songs in Florida.

speaker: Rolla Southworth
words: Rolla Southworth: Well, Dr. Corse it would really seem that we have finally grown up as a nation when we can spend the day recording such folklore as we have heard today. And this is only the beginning and in only one city. Think of the endless material alone throughout Florida. Now although we are in the deep South, our state, with Mr. Call, has a very cosmopolitan group. As a matter of fact, the flags of five nations have flown over Florida. Isn't that a fact? And what a wealth of material that will indicate. Personally, my greatest interest is in the Negro Folklore and how justly proud we all are of Zora Hurston whose fine literary ability and wealth of experience has made our recordings possible today.

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: Carita Doggett Corse
words: Thank you, Ms. Southworth.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Can you state your name, your age, and your occupation?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: My name is H. W. Stuckey. I'm 43 years old. I'm a WPA instructor for the blind.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And, uh, you are also a preacher, aren't you, sir? What congregation?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: A missionary Baptist

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now, uh, this isn't part of your usual, as a missionary Baptist, does your church approve of singing?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: No sir, no sir, they do not.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: You're going to help us out with these, however?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Yes sir, in order to preserve these songs of my childhood days on a farm in South Carolina.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now you have one, you have that holler, that uh?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Yes sir.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What, would you explain something about how it was used and when or something like that?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Yes sir

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead. Tell me something about it.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Let me interrupt you here. Now that, that, what would you call that?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: It's a farm song, made up between the boys plowing on two or more plantations; one would holler 'Hallo' and the other would answer with a second 'Hallo'. That would be a signal for knocking off time for noon, for dinner.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Suppose you give the effect of actually being out on the farm?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: About the fish vendor?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: No, no there's another one without words.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Yes, yes. Just a minute.

speaker: Zora Neale Hurston
words: The one without the words.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: OH, yes, yes. It was usually used in the afternoon mostly when the boys were knocking off work and going in to clean up or going out to call on their girls at night.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How would it sound, suppose someone had just haerd it, what would they hear?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where would the two of them be?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Well, it'd be in the afternoon and they usually had one big plantation a well where the boys from the different fields would water their stock. And they would be unhooking from the plowers, the planters, and distributers, and going to water their mules and put them in the lot for the night when they start these hollers.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Would they be near each other? Or? Or?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Possibly sometimes a quarter mile or a half a mile away

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Would you do it again? Was it the same effect between a quarter mile [inaudible] do a quarter mile.

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Shall I make an explanation of this? Yes sir.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: during my early childhood days in Lee County, SC, my brother-in-law used to carry me about with him at night to these old fashioned dances and he called sets. They would also send for him for 10 or 15 miles around to come and call sets. And one of the songs that I remember well is like this.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Are there more verses to that?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: No that's all I remember.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Will you sing that, will you repeat the point [inaudible]

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Alright.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now, Those last directions, were they taught, is that what he called out for them to do?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Yes sir.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What do they do on the song part, I mean.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: They'd be dancing.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: They'd be dancing.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: When they said do it the right, they'd be swinging their partners to the right and choosing, changing partners.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I see. The last part was giving directions. The rest of the time they were dancing.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Yes sir

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What kind of dancing were they doing?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Well, old fashioned slow dancing is all I knew, they called it.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Go ahead.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: There was an old gentleman when I was a little boy in Sumter, South Carolina, who used to go around the streets selling fish. And this was the song that he would sing in the morning as he came down Manning Avenue where I lived and other streets throughout the city and could be heard for quite a distance, several blocks, singing.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Is that you as a kid? You learned it as a boy?

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: Yes, sir, I wrote, 9 or 10 years old.

speaker: H. W. Stuckey
words: During my early boyhood days I had to nurse my sister's children. I wasn't, being my sight being affected I would not work on the farm and they made me nurse the children. These are some of the songs I liked to sing with the babies in my arms in the, under the tree shade or sometimes on the porch.

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: Irene Jackson

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How old are you?

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: I'll be 40 my next birthday.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And where were you brought up?

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: In South Jacksonville, FL.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And what is it, tell us about what you are going to sing?

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: It's just a play we used to have when we were children and we would be playing church and then rather than sing church songs, we'd make up our songs and we called it our 'play church'.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: You did? Well, woud you start in with?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: When you were small did you play it with a guitar.

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: No, I was just playing with it since then.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: You're playing it with a guitar since then. Why are you singing it with a guitar? Can you sing it without?

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: Yes, I could.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, would you try it without?

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: Yes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Try it without.

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: [Bang] Oh my god.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: That's alright. Don't worry about it. Go ahead.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And that's one you used to, you used to play games to that?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Explain about that.

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: Well, we would be having service and it was time for our preacher to preach though. He couldn't preach out the bible so we'd just take a word and add on and go to preaching. We'd be out in the yard.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, where was this? Where would you be? You wouldn't be doing it in the church.

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: No, we'd be out in the yard.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Just playing.

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: Clean.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Uh-huh

speaker: Irene Jackson
words: The closing part of children's sermon that we used to have.

speaker: Unknown
words: [Laughter]

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: Alabama Singleton. I am 33-years-old.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And where were you brought up?

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: Savannah, GA

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And, uh, what are you going to [inaudible]

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: A play that we used to play when we were children in Savannah.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And what was it called?

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: A ring play, just a ring play, a children's ring play

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright. Sing.

speaker: Distortion
words: [Distortion]

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How did they play that?

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: A ring play, yes. When you say 'go all around the maypole' you'll join hands and be going around the ring and then you're showing your emotion and doing a little dance.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well now, how do you, was there somebody [inaudible].

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: In the middle of the ring and the rest of the children would be patting their hands.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Could you pat the way they did? Take it over again and do the patting.

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: Yes.

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: Alright

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: Well, when you throw around the maypole you doesn't pat because your hands be joined then.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Oh, I see, well sing that and don't do your hands [Inaudible].

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now, what kind of motion would they do?

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: Oh, shucks. There'd be motion of their feets. [Laughter]

speaker: Alabama Singleton
words: Well, there was a man in Savannah Georgia used to sell watermelons and he would come through every morning early and we'd hear him sing.

speaker: Maggie Fulton
words: Maggie Fulton

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [Inaudible] Just sitting down is alright. Well no, I want to get it close to you. I'm going to put it around here.  Now, you just face in that direction. Talk right out. [Adjusts the microphone].

speaker: Maggie Fulton
words: Maggie Fulton

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And how old are you?

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Tell us about this game. Where you learned it.

speaker: Maggie Fulton
words: Well I learned it at my home in Leesville, South Carolina, a little childhood play. The play goes like this.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well, what, how did it go on? What else happened? What happened in the game?

speaker: Maggie Fulton
words: Well, the children would act as if they were flying like the turkeys.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: As if they were flying like a turkey? How was it played and how did they start off play

speaker: Maggie Fulton
words: So they start off playing all over so if you're standing around and one would say 'Little girl, little girl have you been to the barn' and everyone said, yes Ma'am. And they answered 'Did you see my turkey?'' You say 'Yes Ma'am'. And you say 'How high did it fly' and you say 'So high' and then everybody stretched their arms up as if it was the wingspan.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now you'll have to talk a little bit louder now on the next game.

speaker: Maggie Fulton
words: Alright

speaker: Maggie Fulton
words: Just a little barnyard play

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Alright. How does it go?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Harold B. Hazelhurst (HBH): I'm 30 yrs old, born in Georgia, reared in Florida, a water boy on the Marlboro camp, introduces a song.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And where were you brought up?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: I was born in Georgia and reared in Florida.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Where did you learn this particular song?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: I learned this song in middle Florida.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: How did you learn it?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: I was water boy on the hard road camp and the men during the day would sing these songs while they were working.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What is this one called?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Uh, it was called . . . it didn't have no particular name. They called it 'the Captain's Mule.'

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: I like that. Alright. Let's hear it.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: You say that was sung on the hard road camp?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Yes, sir.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What would they sing it for?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Well, it was during the day when it was warm weather and the fellows would get kind of jaded and they'd sing that to get themselves aroused again and to get more interested in their work

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: What kind of work were they doing?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: They were driving wheelers, driving mules on graded camp.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And these were the mule-skinners who were doing the singing? And what do they do? Sing the song while they were [inaudible]

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Sing the song as the mules were going up and down the grade, loading.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: And what is the name of this song?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: The name of this song is 'John Henry'

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Now how did you happen to learn it?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: During the time that I was a water boy, between the age of 15 and 16 on a logging camp railroad. The men during the day would sing this while they were driving spikes.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: While they were driving spikes. Could you mark off how the hammers would be coming down? Just where they'd be coming, hitting against this.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Like that.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Yeah, that would be good.

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Well, they'd be double-driving.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: [Banging] Alright. Can you, You can double-drive as long as you don't double-drive on the microphone. Alright. That's fine. Now, uh, and, This is 'John' -- you were telling me that this 'John Henry' wasn't sung the same way always? I mean, they wouldn't begin --

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Well, no, they wouldn't begin at the same place all the time. Sometimes they'd begin when he was only six months old or perhaps they would begin by John Henry he had a little woman.

speaker: Herbert Halpert
words: Well now tell me, uh, but did they always have the same tune to it?

speaker: Harold B. Hazelhurst
words: Oh yes, they had the same tune all the time but different wording. You know. They would make up words all the time.
